citation.article-title: Knoellia sinensis gen. nov., sp. nov. and Knoellia subterranea sp. nov., two novel actinobacteria isolated from a cave.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Knoellia (Knoell'i.a. N.L. fem. n. Knoellia after Hans Knöll (1913-1978), a German pioneer in antibiotic research)
Cells are irregular rods and cocci, occurring singly, in pairs, short chains or clusters.
Rods vary in their dimensions from 1.7 to 6.0 by 0.4 to 1.2 μm and cocci in diameter from 0.6 to 1.4 μm.
Gram-positive, not acidfast, non-motile, non-sporulating and exhibit a rod/coccus growth cycle.
The peptidoglycan is of the A-1γ type (based on meso-A2 μm, direct cross-linkage).
MK-7(H4) and MK-6(H4) may occur in trace amounts.

The cellular fatty acid profile is characterized by the predominance of 13-methyltetradecanoic (i-C15:0), 15-methylhexadecanoic (i-C17:0, 14-methylpentadecanoic (i-C16:0) and 14-methylhexadecanoic (ai-C17:0 acids.
The major polar lipids are phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol, diphosphatidylglycerol.
The DNA G+C content is 68-69 mol%.
Phylogenetically, this genus is a member of the suborder Micrococcineae, order Actinomycetales.
The type species is Knoellia sinensis.
